I've at least dabbled in all the Battlefield games from Battlefield 2 upwards, but I have to say that this is the best one for a fair number of reasons. To find out why follow me... I'll be reporting from inside the fight! (Races off towards distant towering explosions erupting over the war-shattered horizon, stubs toe, cries.)  If you're after single player Bad Company 2 brings some fairly smart level design with a sharp, fairly witty script that approaches like a Shane Black movie. It's not screen-writing brilliance or anything, but it has a far greater sense of fun and playfulness than its increasingly tedious sequels and the latter Call of Duty games. No dark and gritty moping about here, purporting to show the 'horrors' of war whilst quivering with lust over the latest sniper scope attachment, nope. Just four Bro-Force men (or rather three and a mandatory smart-aleck quipping Shane Black staple) taking down the bad guys like out of some Kelly's Heroes meets Commando movie. So yeah, not genius, but fun. Battlefield 3's snooze-inducing 'arty' debriefing scenes framework nearly made me break my nose on the computer desk, so lethargic they made me. I cannot really recall Battlefield 4's at all. Plus the game is a lot less linear than subsequent outings, where you get to use the completely destructible scenery to its fullest advantage to forge new paths in completing a level.  ('The stretched twig of peace is at melting point...')   Graphics! Well, they're very nice. Sure, Battlefield 3 & 4 have slightly shinier, more detailed graphics with slightly more convincing character animations and lens flare coo-worthy prettiness. But really, these graphics more than do the job. Dust clouds from descending helicopters, litter blowing in the streets, shockwaves rippling, shrapnel flying through the air... it's all here. And it won't tax your modern day computer too much neither. And there isn't too much going on to distract from the gunplay and everything runs smooth, so you won't be visually overwhelmed whilst trying to pick off the bad guys so much.  And this game has the joint best audio of any game ever. The co-achiever of this award goes to The Long Dark, and its tremendously atmospheric sparse soundtrack and wonderful environmental sound. But Bad Company 2 has something magical called 'The War Tapes', activate it and feel like 1990's CNN war correspondent Peter Arnett fired by the NEWS CANNON of an Abraham Tank into the SOUNDS OF A WAR MIXED BY THE DERANGED PHIL SPECTOR HIMSELF. Ahem. Basically it's just a rather fantastic mix of panicky crackling intercom messages, wonderful bass-rumbling cannon fire and the sound of bullets zipping past your ears. You need headphones to really do it justice.   ('...people here are very much bursting with war...')  So, you all know the basics of how it plays, no doubt. But how's the multiplayer? Well, it's the best in the series. This is beautifully balanced shooter created before kill-streak bonuses and landfill-stuffing +0.2% shotgun-accuracy unlocks smothered fun like a big statty-based tidal wave of squinty misery. There's four classes performing the roles of assault, medic, anti-tank and recon sniper. The recon sniper is the smartest tweak of the set, as the game encourages snipers to move closer to the action with such toys as C4 and movement sensors. The game gives them fun close quarter pistols and ways to support the team from the front lines. You can also snipe too, and have fun doing it, but you can no longer prone. This encourages movement, and forces snipers to quit camping and instead rove the buildings of a battlefield, picking off hapless players and then fleeing the area as enraged victims bring the upper floors crashing down upon their noggin.   Yes, crashing floors. Practically all the buildings in Bad Company 2 can be blown apart piece by piece until the entire edifice comes a-tumbling down in a avalance of masonry-mayhem. It makes for great tactical play too. Using a grenade launcher to create a new entrance point never gets old, especially if Johnny-Foe is caught on the other side of the impromptu door opening. Yup, by the end of the battle few structures remain unscathed.   ('...this very much is a country about to blow up in it's own face.'   The maps are very good, with shout-outs going to Panama Canal, Arica Harbour and Oasis as to my mind the best three. I also have a fondness for the atmospheric snowy levels. The only maps I don't like are Harvest Day and Heavy Metal, which are vehicle dominated. I find it very hard to get a good footing on either of them, and the lack of cover makes trying to get around an abject misery. Not much room for tactical play either. Predictably, they seem to be the most popular on the servers. Gngh and argh.  What else? Well, it all seems a bit more fluid and smoother than the latter Battlefields. Wiser and more knowledgable heads might nod knowingly and mutter the words, 'netcode', or something, but I've got no real idea why. All I know is it feels more fun to me. And I guess that's the important thing. SO. If you're itching to buy a military-themed multiplayer shooter with lots of vehicles and explosions and scenes unfolding like the best bits of Apocalypse Now, then get this one. It's pretty much the only one you'll need and is far less depressing than the 'mature' ponderous tosh forced on us nowadays.   In Summary:   COMPLETELY BANG! BAD COMPANY 2 IS SO ENTHUSIASTICALLY WAR IT'S BRINGING YOU ANOTHER TEAR ON THE FACE OF THE WORLD'S MOTHER. 9 / 10  P.S: Apologies for the excess of The Day Today references.

The best Battlefield. The map design is excellent; it prioritizes fun engagements above all else. Maps are largely built around prefab, destructible, 2-3 floor buildings, which buffer the flow of combat and compartmentalize individual encounters. This means that you can actually breathe and make meaningful decisions in between all of the twitch-based watch-every-corner assaults. You know that segment in every battlefield scene where two soldiers duck behind cover and banter, using the moment of calm to rest and survey their surroundings before leaping back out guns blazing? This game is all about that moment. Front lines move back and forth in a perceivable way, you can get caught in epic holdouts with your squad, and buildings take a LOT of damage before they collapse, with each blown-out wall potentially changing your tactics. And despite how dynamic things get, you never burn out. Because you can breathe.  Oh, and there are NO JETS, which means that A) Infantry can meaningfully engage every vehicle, B) no player has to dedicate themself exclusively to countering air units, C) air units are easy to keep track of, and D) air combat remains cover-based and low-flying. The whole 'battlefield' experience is much more tightly woven together as a result.

This game is a real piece of work, not necessarily in a bad way though.   The Singleplayer experience is okay, its got a pretty decent story spanning ww2 and modern day war scenarios, even has you crash a satellite and recover its black box.  It's version of the Battlefield Frostbite engine allows for completly destroying buildings with c4, instead of the more modern one seen in battlefield 3 and even battlefield 4 where only bits and pieces of buildings can be destroyed(not counting the specific scripted events in battlefield 4 where you can demolish a skyscraper or blow up a dam).  It's Multiplayer aspect is a bit lacking, there is no proning, there is a very bad latency problem which only seems to clear up if you run this game with a medium to top tier computer and wookies (ghillie suit snipers) dominate most maps.  Its business model is a bit bad, as it has 2 DLC, one adds a new map and weapons and thats fine, but the other unlocks all the top tier weapons for each class, or rather provides you with exact replicas.  Note that the weapons which are unlocked are top tier but aren't necessarily the best weapons in the game.  Overall even though this game like all games has its flaws and some are worse than others, it's still worth looking into and playing with friends. What can I say about this game that isn't gonna take up a whole lot of room? To save all the hapless text that bores the stuff out of you, yes, I DO recommend this game if you're interested in an FPS game. I'm not gonna say this game is flawless in every conceivable angle, because obviously this is not the case. From my experiences of playing this, I should point out a few things that you should know going in:  1: This is a game that plays by its own twisted sense of reality. This is a rule you can pretty much apply to every game ever. While Battlefield: Bad Company 2 acts generally like any old FPS game, there are many things that seem to more or less break the fourth wall. For example, the spotting system has flaws with which you can see the enemy behind cover for a few seconds in the form of a red triangle above their head. This can lead to exploits involving players getting shot just as they leap from cover if not outright getting killed through smoke, garage doors, or rubble. Also worth mentioning is that many weapons function awkwardly from a more common-sense means of use which may seem suspicious. For example, the bolt-action rifles have uncanny hipfire accuracy that is almost reliable. That's not to say there isn't an extreme, though, if someone has 'overdosed on Ritalin.'  2: This is a TEAM game. It is highly important you keep this in mind, because I've been through countless matches where my teammates/enemies do little more than camp in the deployment zones without playing the objective and snipe, attempting vainfully to pad their K/D. K/D is only half the battle in this game. It's good to balance trying to get kills/assists, playing the objective, and scoring points by helping your teammates do the same. The four classes each have their own support gadget (Ammo Boxes, Medkits, Repair Tools, and Motion Sensors) - use them wherever it is most advantageous. While you can get an ace pin going 0/98 by playing total support (*cough* medic *cough*), someone on your team still has to bear the burden.   3: This game is nearly, if not, five years old right now at the time I originally typed this. As a result of EA and DICE having released  Battlefield 3  Battlefield 4, the game feels less populated than it once was, which is a damn shame. The game released after BC2 is billed as a sequel to the 2005 original Battlefield 2, but it just feels like a watered down BC2 in retrospect. I wanted to like the game, but it just didn't feel the same, and I kept looking back to Bad Company 2 because EA and DICE just seemed to... get it more on the mark, in my opinion at least. True, it does have quite a few flaws, and some rigs may not be totally optimized for the game even if they are technically able to run the game itself, but it has a charm, and I guess I have a soft spot for this game myself. Maybe that's just my ability to adjust to its crap factor, though. I dunno.  If there ever is a sequel to Bad Company 2, I'd be interested to at least look at it. But I'd be praying it's not gonna look like   Battlefield 3 OR   Battlefield 4. BC2's own sequel should look like the other Bad Company games; maybe touch up the graphics a little if they feel they should, but besides the point. It should also play like those games as well; maybe nerf a few weapons or snap that bolt hipfire anomaly. That is just my opinion, though, and obviously I have to see it for myself to believe it can hold true. But the route EA DICE went   after releasing Battlefield 3   makes me doubt if they could make a game that is nearly as good anymore.  That being said, I like this game. Will you find enjoyment in this game, too? Probably. Probably not. Obviously it depends on your taste or if you even like FPS games at all. But check it out when you see a sale pop up sometime.  EDIT: Don't get me wrong. BF4 is pretty good.

Very brief mention - this is a REVIEW. I hope people get the common ♥♥♥♥ing sense to write REVIEWS on these pages instead of little stories or cooking recipes. It and anybody who does that are completely pathetic.  Now, moving on...  I was a veteran of this game on the Xbox 360 - when I say veteran, I mean I recognize the sounds of each gun being shot from afar, even the suppressed weapons. I got lots of enjoyment out of it, and I couldn't help but 'upgrade' to the PC version. I upgraded for several reasons:  1) I felt that more people played the PC version, since that's the target console of the series. 2) I was sure that the graphics would be improved on the PC. 3) I would be able to browse servers instead of just doing a mandatory quick match on the 360.  Within about half an hour I got all three of those points addressed.  1) There are FAR more people on the PC version as opposed to the Xbox 360. There aren't tons of full servers, but there are still a rather stunning number of people with taste in terms of Battlefield games. 2) The graphics. Holy CRAP. 60 fps without tweaking a single setting. Overwhelming lighting effects. Much larger and more detailed levels. 3) Server browsing is just as useful as I suspected it would be. There is a glitch, however, where when you start up the game and go under server browsing, there's an empty list - don't fret; the fix is to simply press 'Search', and they all load in.  Now, in terms of gameplay; it's perfectly balanced and hectic gameplay that rewards players of all playstyles, both infantry and vehicular. It stays basic without falling to the crap that Battlefield 3 and Battlefield 4 brought to the table; there's none of that 'lengthy reload on an empty magazine' BS; there's no suppression; you don't wake up from a nap after getting revived, only to get shot again; there's no vehicle healing or crippling; no crazy weapon attachments...  None of that crap is present here. If you want more of that, don't buy this game.  The singleplayer took a shot to the head in comparison to its predecessor (an Xbox 360/PS3 exclusive; I wish it were on the PC, too :,C), in the regard to how boring it was, and how fast you'll shoot through it. There's a video on YouTube (it should still be up) of somebody beating the campaign in just slightly over THREE HOURS. Enemies die in one or two shots, which renders all challenge moot, everything is scripted and hideously linear, and there's little to no point playing it. The four main characters just become dreadfully unlikable in the campaign; again, in stark opposition to the first game. With the sole exception of Battlefield: Bad Company (1), all BF games' strengths are in their multiplayer.  So do I recommend this game? YES. ABSOLUTELY. It was phenomonal on the Xbox 360, and it's equally as nice on the PC. It has better ease-of-access when it comes to finding matches, better graphics, and is just completely mindblowing.  And, of course, it has a massive Vietnam War expansion/conversion...

Bad Company 2 is an awesome game and in my eyes by far the best multiplayer shooter I've ever played. I played this game for 600hrs on PS3, and I missed it so much after being disappointed by BF3 and especially BF4 that I've purchased it again for the PC.   Unlike the recent Battlefields from BF3 onwards, Bad Company 2 is less complicated and overloaded - and that's what makes it brilliant. I have to admit, I'm a huge vehicle freak and I only play Battlefield to fly helicopters and jets online (although there are no jets in BC2). I never got used to the new Battlefields with all the auto-lock weapons spamming at you and never really enjoyed it much when even jet pilots barely used their guns and relied solely on their auto-lock weapons. In Bad Company 2, there is no such thing as auto-lock. It's all about skill. If someone is better than you, he will get you - not because you run out of flares but because he was faster or smarter. Likewise, if you are better, nobody will shoot you down. That's how competitive multiplayer gameplay is supposed to be, not what the new Battlefields are like. While I concentrate on air vehicles, the same can be said about everything in this game. Every weapon (system) has a certain feel to it and can be mastered in a way that makes you seem overpowered compared to other players. But, since only very few people truly master a class or a vehicle, the game is generally more balanced and predictable, which makes it easier for new players to get a hang of it. You don't just die out of nowhere because someone with a higher rank used a weapon system only unlocked later in the game - the unlocks generally don't make a class better, they just offer you more weapons to chose of and that makes it fun to try out different sets or classes because you don't have to worry being 'underarmed' compared to others.  No matter what your style of playing is, wether you're a sniper seeking out your kills from a distance or a tanker supporting your infantry when taking a base - the series rises up to its full potential only when you play as a team. Bad Company 2 encourages teamplay in a way I've never seen in the more recent Battlefield. I can't really put a finger on why that exactly is, I can only assume it is because classes are more limited and vehicles don't heal themselves that players rely more on each other and work together.  Another thing great about this game are the maps. Not only do they work well with Rush and Conquest, they each have strategies to them and depending on which path to an objective you take you will experience very different gameplay. It's not a random arena in that people run around in circles seeking for the next kill, it's a real Battlefield in which you can flank enemies or directly assault them.   Bad Company 2 is what Battlefield really is about. There are less weapons, less vehicles, less gadgets and the maps are smaller - but when everything works out, when two good teams meet each other and you sit in your attack helicopter being shot at from all sides, evading infantry launched rockets, tanks, enemy helicopters, having to stay back because every player is a threat - even for a helicopter - and you support your team overhead keeping a base clean for the tanks and infantry to take a flag, when you are truly concentrated and the atmosphere so dense you need a break after the match, that's when you will play your best and most exciting multiplayer matches you have ever played.   As this is the PC version, I have to say though that especially the vehicle controls are quite insensitive and everything moves a bit slower than on console. Nevertheless, go buy it and experience the Battlefield feeling for yourself. You wont regret it.

I am reviewing this having twice tried to play the game. I find it thoroughly unenjoyable, yet I keep coming back to try it again to remind myself why I dislike it. My only theory as to why I do this is that EA Games has mastered the use of Stockholm Syndrome as a marketing device.  Of the myriad faults I find in this game, the worst offender is the gameplay. You control a soldier who appears to suffer from an impairment of the inner ear. He bobs and weaves in a manner which falls quite short of what I can only assume is intended to be 'realistic'. This bobbing and swaying, in conjunction with the wild bucking of any firearm you so much as point at an enemy, resulted in my experiencing a wave of nausea much akin to that one might experience during a screening of ‘The Blair Witch Project’ or ‘Cloverfield’ ( these being two films I also don't recommend). This sensation encouraged me to try and take cover and move around as little as required, however as you walk at a speed rivalled by the still life paintings of Norman Rockwell (which is to say, very, very slowly) you will likely find yourself holding down the movement buttons out of necessity to keep up with your better balanced compatriots.  Speaking of your teammates, I would like it noted that I find the decision to send a group of people stricken with acute cognitive delay into combat to be highly questionable both in efficacy and ethic. While at first I found their penchant for calling out enemy locations only after being struck by several bullets to be endearingly inept, but I soon realized there were more tragic circumstances as to why my teammates were performing so poorly. This epiphany came to me when I witnessed the entire team hunkering down, unable to progress due to a sole enemy soldier, blocking their way as he stood amidst his fallen comrades. The enemy soldier refused to retreat, presumably due either to his being left in a fugue state after having his peers gunned down before his eyes, or to outright confusion at the sudden cowardice offered by this pack of bloodthirsty operatives he had singlehandedly pinned down behind some barrels nearby. I winced and sported a sympathetic if pained expression when I hear my team speak up,  'Help us out here… I think there's one left!'  I would like to take this opportunity to commend the American military for its equal opportunity hiring practices. It was very clear that these developmentally impaired patriots were doing the best they could muster in the battlefield. It wasn’t their lack of fire support or situational awareness, rather it was their heart and indomitable spirit in the face of adversity that won me over and brought a tear to my eye.   Finally, I would steer people away from this game because of the 'story', told by means of a cut scene every other firefight/10 minutes of gameplay. It would be offering undue charity to pose that the plot 'makes no sense'. Indeed, I suspect it may have been created using a computer program developed in the passing of Tom Clancy in an attempt to generate ridiculous politically charged plotlines for retail media (I have also theorized that Tom Clancy himself may well have been this computer program all along). At any rate, the plot is childishly non sequitur, having the player span the globe fighting Russian troops (!?) to secure a mysterious weapon developed by the Japanese during WWII.
